title: Presidential hotels add history to fun activities
text:
Presidential hotels add history to fun activities Travel 
Powered by Local Corporation By Lynn O'Rourke Hayes The Dallas Morning News • Sunday July 19, 2015 5:00 AM 
Pair history with exploration when you and the family check into a hotel inspired by a U.S. president. Here are five to consider. 
• The Jefferson, Washington, D.C.: Get comfortable in this famed hotel and learn about the epicurean, intellectual, farmer, inventor and president for whom it was named. 
Kids will get a kick out of the free “Where’s Tommy?” tour of locations where Thomas Jefferson is remembered. Return to the hotel and you’ll be rewarded with a treat, compliments of the chef. 
Visit www.jeffersondc.com 
• The President Abraham Lincoln hotel, Springfield, Ill.: Learn about the 16th president during your stay in the city that houses Lincoln’s presidential library and museum. Visit the well-regarded center featuring exhibits, artifacts, theatrical presentations and guest speakers of interest to the whole family. 
Visit www.alplm.org 
• U.S. Grant hotel, San Diego: The grand hotel was renovated by the 18th president’s son. Enjoy classic architecture combined with modern decor for a relaxing and luxurious family getaway. 
Visit www.usgrant.net 
• McKinley Grand Hotel, Canton: This independent boutique hotel is the ideal home base from which to learn about the 25th president. Visit the William McKinley Presidential Library and Museum for hands-on science exhibits and a planetarium. 
The McKinley Gallery chronicles the path of a leader who was teaching in a country school when the Civil War broke out. 
Travelers can also visit the nearby Pro Football Hall of Fame. 
Visit www.mckinleygrandhotel.com or www.mckinleymuseum.org 
• The Roosevelt, New Orleans: Book the Family Fun package and create a memorable family getaway in the Big Easy. 
This historic 504-room hotel was officially named in 1923 to honor President Theodore Roosevelt and recognize his efforts to build the Panama Canal, an event that served the city of New Orleans well. 
Just steps beyond the old-world grandeur of the hotel, you’ll find the famed French Quarter, shopping, museums, galleries and, of course, music.
